meaning: Consists of practices and technologies designed to protect networks, computers and data from attack or unauthorised access.
Manipulation with the goal of obtaining personal or sensitive information.
An umbrella term referring to various forms of software with malicious intent.
A cyber attack intended to redirect website traffic to a fake website.
The password that comes with a device. Usually 1234, 0000, 1111 or something similar. Easily guessable by hackers
Where users are given access to data that they should not be able to access.
Storage devices that can be connected to a computer. They can be used to put malware on a computer or to steal data from a computer.
Software that does not have the latest security updates, leaving it vulnerable to exploits that were available on older versions.
Attempting to gain access to resources without knowledge of usernames, passwords and other normal means of access.
When the person testing the system has knowledge and possibly basic credentials, simulating an attack from inside the system (a malicious insider)
When the person testing the system has no knowledge of any credentials, simulating an attack from outside the system (an external attack).
Creating an invented scenario to engage a targeted victim, increasing the chance the victim will divulge information or perform actions that would be unlikely in ordinary circumstances.
A technique of fraudulently obtaining private information, often using email or SMS, pretending to be another person or organisation.
Observing a person's private information over their shoulder. For instance cashpoint machine PIN numbers.
A form of malware that replicates itself onto other computer systems, usually with the intention of causing damage.
A form of malware that seems like legitimate software, but in fact contains malicious code.
A form of malware secretly installed on a computer that collects information about the user.
Using unique physical characteristics to identify a user.
Used to tell humans from robots, often asking them to identify image features.
Sending a confirmation email to the user's address with a link that allows the site to verify that the user does own that email.
Prevents human error from leaving software outdated by updating software as soon as a new version is released.
